Award.AwardTitle: Insights into the Burial, Tectonic, and Hydrologic History of the Cenozoic Succession in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica through Analysis of Diagenetic Phases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
This project will use sediment cores from the Victoria Land Basin (VLB), Antarctica, to study secondary (diagenetic) carbonate minerals, as indicators of the basin?s fluid-flow history, within the well-constrained tectonic, depositional, and climatic context provided by sediment cores. This study will provide insights into subsurface processes in Victoria Land Basin, Antarctica and their relationships with the region?s climatic, cryospheric, and tectonic history. The work will utilize cores previously recovered by US-sponsored stratigraphic drilling projects (CIROS, CRP, and ANDRILL projects). This work is motivated by the unexpected discovery of dense brine in the subsurface of Southern McMurdo Sound during drilling by the ANDRILL Southern McMurdo Sound project. The presence of the brine is intriguing because it contradicts previous models for the origin of subsurface fluids that called upon large contributions from glacial melt water. Project objectives involve documenting the distribution of the brine (and potentially other fluids) via characterization of diagenetic precipitates. The approach will involve integration of petrographic and geochemical data (including conventional carbon, oxygen, and ?clumped? isotopes) to fully characterize diagenetic phases and allow development of a robust paragenetic history. This work will provide novel insights into the Cenozoic evolution of the VLB and, more broadly, the role of glacial processes in generating subsurface fluids.

Broader impacts:
Results from this project will help understand the origins of brines, groundwater and hydrocarbon reservoirs in analogous modern and ancient deposits elsewhere, which is of broad interest. This project will support the training of one graduate and one undergraduate student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) providing learning opportunities in sedimentary geology and diagenesis, fields with wide applicability. This proposal emphasizes rapid dissemination of results to the scientific community via conference presentations and contributions to peer-reviewed publications. The results will be integrated into education activities designed to develop skills in petrography and diagenesis, which are highly sought after in the energy sector. The project will generate a well-constrained dataset that allows direct linkage of diagenetic phases to environmental and tectonic change across a large sedimentary basin which will provide the basis for a comprehensive case study in an upper-level course (Sedimentary Petrography and Diagenesis) at UNL. In addition, online exercises will be developed and submitted to an open-access site (SEPM Stratigraphy Web) dedicated to sedimentary geology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the origin, significance, and spatial distribution of dense, high-salinity brine that occurs at depths greater than 250 meters below the seafloor in McMurdo Sound, Antarctica. The presence of this high salinity fluid was unknown until its discovery during drilling activities associated with the Antarctic Drilling Project (ANDRILL). The geochemical composition of the brine demonstrated that it formed as a byproduct of seawater freezing along ice sheet margins in a process known as brine rejection. Due to its high density, the brine sank through the water column and into the subsurface, where it now resides within pore space of sediments that comprise the Cenozoic rock record.

The impetus for this study is several-fold. Results provide novel insight into subsurface processes in on Antarctic shelves and their relationships with the region’s climatic, cryospheric, and tectonic history. Beyond Antarctica, results will provide a basis for interpretation of alteration features in other glacially influenced basins. Such information is particularly critical in developing and managing groundwater and hydrocarbon reservoirs that are housed in analogous modern and ancient deposits that lie outside of areas protected by the Antarctic Treaty System. Recent offshore drilling efforts into glaciomarine deposits, including the ANDRILL project, have been hampered by the unexpected occurrence of deep brines.  By investigating the origin and significance of brine in the Victoria Land Basin, Antarctica, results aid in predicting the potential for encountering such fluids elsewhere. Results may also help resolve controversies surrounding the origin of brines that occur in high-latitude sites under consideration as repositories for nuclear waste.

The brine has a distinctive geochemical fingerprint that it imparts on cements. This fingerprint allows cement compositions to serve as a proxy for brine presence where pore water is not available. The brine fingerprint was recorded in all drill cores examined in McMurdo Sound, indicating that the brine pool extends from at least as far south as McMurdo Station to as far north as Cape Roberts.

Results of this work show that where brine infiltrated sediments via porosity networks, carbonate cements have precipitated. These cements serve to fill porosity and lithify the sediment at a relatively shallow depth compared to sediments that form in other settings. There are recognizable stratigraphic patterns in cementation, which reflect the effect of climate on sea level, sedimentation, and stratigraphic architecture. Decreased input of fine-grained sediments during colder climate regimes resulted in higher permeability deposits that were prone to infiltration by brine upon burial.  By contrast, many climate regimes preserve higher porosities (25 – 45%) and lack significant cementation. Sequence stratigraphic relationships indicate that these porous sandstones are best developed in highstand delta systems that formed during ice minima, when substantial volumes of meltwater were released from glacier termini. Individual sandstone bodies, which likely extend laterally over several kms, tend to be enclosed by muddy lithologies. Porosity in these sandstones was retained due to discharge of dilute meltwater during deposition and subsequent isolation of sands between impermeable barriers. These results will improve our ability to predict the potential of such deposits to serve as reservoirs for water, hydrocarbon, and other fluids.

In addition to driving cementation, the brine interacts chemically with the shells and skeletons of invertebrates and plankton that are used to generate paleoclimate reconstructions that improve understanding of Earth’s climate system. Chemical interaction leads to alteration of original chemical compositions of shells and skeletons, hindering their use in studies of paleoceanography and paleoclimate.   

Application of the clumped isotope paleothermometer allowed cement precipitation temperatures to be determined. Results from the AND-2A core show that the slope defined by cement-derived temperatures versus depth parallels but is offset from the local geothermal gradient. Cements formed at cooler temperatures than expected at their present burial depths. The implication is that the bulk of cements were emplaced when the host sediments were at shallower depths. Relationships between burial-depth, sediment age, and temperature indicate that the bulk of the cements formed during a major Miocene cooling event that led to expansion of Antarctica’s ice sheets. Regardless of exact timing, it is evident that the brine is a longstanding feature of McMurdo Sound.

This project supported the training of two graduate students at UNL and one graduate student at the Rosenstiel School of Marine Sciences at the University of Miami. Students participated in aspects of the research, from data gathering to interpretation and presentation of results. Results were disseminated to the scientific community via conference presentations and submissions to peer-reviewed publications. Outcomes were integrated into education activities designed to develop skills in petrography and diagenesis, which are highly sought after by industry.
